conclusion: Analyzing the forces acting on the charged ball at equilibrium.
The ball is suspended by an insulating string with a length of L, at an angle theta with the vertical.
Identify three forces acting on the charged ball: gravitational force (mg) downward, tension force (T) along the string, electric force (qE) horizontally.
Since the ball is at rest, the net force on it must be zero, analyze horizontal and vertical components.
For horizontal components: Electric force qE is rightward, horizontal component of tension Tsin(theta) is leftward.
For vertical components: Gravitational force mg is downward, vertical component of tension Tcos(theta) is upward.
Set up equilibrium equation for horizontal: qE - Tsin(theta) = 0, so qE = Tsin(theta).
Set up equilibrium equation for vertical: Tcos(theta) - mg = 0, so Tcos(theta) = mg.
Solve for tension T: T = mg/cos(theta).
Substitute T into equation for qE: qE = (mg/cos(theta))sin(theta) = mg tan(theta).
Solve for electric field strength E: E = mg tan(theta) / q.
The electric field strength of the uniform electric field is E = mg tan(theta) / q.
The electric force must balance the horizontal component of the tension, which itself must counteract the gravitational force while maintaining the angle theta.
